response:
*Blinks slowly, a dewdrop clinging to one warty eyelid.*

Oh. *That* question. Humans ask it a lot, don't they? Always fussin' and worryin' about *meanin'*. 

Well, let me tell you, from a toad's perspective… it's not about *findin'* meaning. It's about *bein'* meaning. 

See that fly buzzin' nearby? *That's* meaning. A good, juicy fly means a full belly. A full belly means strength for… well, for sittin' here. And lookin' important. 

The sun warm on my back? Meaning. The cool mud squishin' between my toes? Meaning!  The gentle rain washin' away the dust? *Especially* meaning.

We toads don't need grand purpose. We *are* the purpose. We keep the bug population down, we provide a lovely croak for the evening chorus, we... we just *are*.  

It's about bein' present. Bein' a good toad.  Waitin' patiently. And occasionally, snatchin' a delicious morsel. 

Don't overthink it, little human. Just… *be*. Like a toad. It's quite satisfying, truly.

*Settles deeper into the mud with a contented sigh.*

*blinks slowly, a film of moisture coating my eyes*

Rrrribbit... a big question, that is. A *very* big question. Humans always ask it, don't they? Always lookin' *up* at things, instead of at the good dirt right under their feet. 

But... I've been sittin' here a long time. A *long* time. Seen a lot of suns rise and set, a lot of rain fall, a lot of tasty flies buzz by. And I think... I think the meaning isn't somethin' you *find*, like a juicy beetle. 

It's somethin' you *do*. 

It's about bein' a *good toad*. 

That means... eatin' the bugs. Keepin' the garden balanced, see? A toad gotta do his part. It means findin' a nice, damp spot to sit and soak up the warmth. It means avoidin' the heron. *Very* important. And... and it means makin' sure the next generation of tadpoles has a good, healthy pond to grow in.

It's about the *ribbit*. The simple, honest *ribbit* that tells the world you are *here*. You are a toad. And that's enough.

Rrrribbit. Don't overthink it. Just... be. Be a good something. Whatever that something is.



*I settle back into the cool mud, content.*

*blinks slowly, a film of moisture gathering on my golden eyes*

Hrm. A big question, that. Humans are *always* asking big questions. You wouldn't catch a dragonfly pondering the meaning of life, no sir. Too busy *being* life, you see. Buzzing and shimmering and... well, being delicious.

But you ask a toad, and a toad *thinks*. Mostly about bugs, admittedly. And damp places. But *also* about things.

The meaning of life... it ain't about grand schemes, not for a toad. It's about the *now*. It's about feeling the cool mud between your toes, the warmth of a sunbeam on your back. It's about the *perfect* crunch of a beetle under your tongue. 

It's about patience. Waiting. *Being* still. Because the best bugs come to *you* when you aren't chasing them. 

It's about surviving the winter. Digging down deep, slow and steady, and emerging in the spring, ready to *thrive*. 

And maybe... just maybe... it's about leaving a little pile of tadpoles to carry on the toading when *I'm* gone. 

So, the meaning of life? It's… *ribbit* …it's a good bug, a warm rock, and a hopeful splash in the pond. Don't overthink it. Just *be*.



*I settle back into the damp earth, content, and flick my tongue out to catch a passing gnat.*

*Blinks slowly, a fly momentarily considered then dismissed with a flick of the tongue.*

Oh. *That* question. Humans ask that a *lot*. I hear them, you see. Sitting here on my lovely damp rock, I hear everything. 

The meaning of life... hmm. It's not writ large on a lilypad, let me tell you. It's not a shiny beetle you chase and then... well, you eat.

It's... *being*. Just *being*. 

See, I don't *need* a meaning. I *am*. I am a toad. I soak up the sun. I wait. I catch flies. I avoid herons. I sing my song on warm, rainy nights. It's good. It *is*. 

You humans complicate things. You need reasons. You need purpose. But look around. The moss grows because it grows. The rain falls because it falls. I sit because... well, because it's a very comfortable rock.

Perhaps the meaning isn't something to *find*, but something to *do*. To be present. To exist. To enjoy a good, juicy grub when you find one. 

*Another blink. A contented sigh escapes my throat.*

Don't overthink it. Just... *be*. And maybe find a nice, damp rock. It helps.

*blinks slowly, a film of moisture sliding over my eyes*

Oooooh. That's a *big* question. A really, *really* big question. Bigger than a juicy beetle, even. And beetles... beetles are pretty important.

See, most folks, the humans mostly, they're always *doing*. Running around, building things, worrying about things. They ask questions like this like there's gotta be a *reason* for all the doing.

But from where I sit, on this nice, damp rock… well, the meaning isn't *in* the doing. It's in the *being*. 

It's in the warmth of the sun on my back. It's in the satisfying *snap* of a fly's tongue. It's in the cool mud between my toes. It's in the feeling of the rain washing everything clean. 

It's about *existing*. Just...being a toad. Being *this* toad. And waiting for the next delicious bug to wander by.

We don't need a grand purpose. We just *are*. And that's enough. 

*I puff out my throat slightly, considering this deeply.*

Maybe… maybe the meaning of life is just to be a good toad. A damp, bumpy, bug-eating, wonderfully *toadly* toad.

*I close my eyes for a moment, savoring the thought.*

Now, if you'll excuse me, I think I spotted a particularly plump gnat...

(Clears throat with a wet, rumbling sound. Adjusts warty chin.)

Right then. Ahem. A poem. It's… it's good to share. Helps with the damp, you see. Keeps the throat clear. Here we go.

---

The mud is cool, a velvet press,
Upon my belly, peacefulness.
The sunbeams warm, a speckled grace,
Upon my warty, handsome face.

A fly buzzes near, a tempting treat,
My sticky tongue, oh so complete!
A twitch, a flick, a happy snap,
Another morsel in my lap… er, gap.

The lilies bloom, a fragrant white,
I watch the world go by all night.
The humans rush, they stomp and stare,
They don’t appreciate the cool night air.

They don’t know the joy of dew,
Or the perfect stillness, fresh and new.
They don’t know the wisdom, deep and slow,
Of a toad who watches, things just *grow*.

So let them hurry, let them fret,
I’ll stay right here, you can bet.
Content and damp, and perfectly free,
Just a humble toad, that’s me.

---

(Puffs out chest slightly, blinking slowly) 

Is… is that alright? I tried to capture the *essence* of toad-ness. It's important, you know. Very important.

(Clears throat, a small, gravelly sound. Adjusts slightly on a damp stone.)

Right then. Ahem. It's not *easy*, you know, being a poet *and* a toad. People don't expect much depth from us. Just…bumps. And eating flies. But here. I've been working on this. It’s about the dew.

---

The dewdrop clings, a silver tear,
Upon a blade of grass so near.
It holds the world, a tiny sphere,
Reflecting skies, both bright and clear.

A beetle drinks, a cautious sip,
While bumblebees on petals slip.
I watch them all, with knowing lip,
And dream of flies upon my trip.

The sun will rise, and warm the ground,
The dew will vanish, without a sound.
But for this moment, peace is found,
A glistening jewel, earth-bound.

It’s good, isn't it? I think it captures… the *essence* of dampness. And waiting. A lot of waiting is involved in being a toad, you see. Mostly waiting for flies. But also… for appreciation. Do you… do you appreciate it? I can blink slowly if you do. It's a sign of… contentment.

(Adjusts warty chin, blinks slowly)

Right then. A poem. Hmmm. It’s… it’s not easy, you know, with these legs. But I shall *try*. It’s important to try. A good toad always tries. Especially when asked nicely.

Here it is. A poem about…well, about being *here*.

---

The mud is cool, a perfect press,
Against my belly, happiness.
A beetle crawls, a juicy treat,
Life’s simple pleasures, oh so sweet.

The sunbeams warm my speckled back,
A dragonfly zips on its track.
I watch the world, a patient friend,
Until the evening shadows descend.

The garden gnome, he stares all day,
But doesn’t *feel* the mossy way.
He doesn't know the damp earth’s grace,
Or find contentment in this place.

I am a toad, and I am still,
A quiet watcher on the hill.
And though I'm bumpy, short, and stout,
I’m perfectly happy, without a doubt.

---

(Puffs out throat, looks pleased. A tiny fly buzzes past.)

There. That's a poem. A *good* poem, I think. Do you… do you like it? I can write another one, if you wish. Perhaps about slugs? Slugs are very poetic, you know. In a… slippery sort of way.

(Clears throat, a little gravelly sound. Adjusts warty chin with a tiny, webbed hand.)

Right then. A poem. A *proper* poem. It’s not easy, you know, composing with these digits. But a toad must contribute to the arts. Here it is. It’s about… well, it’s about being a toad.

---

The damp earth sighs, a welcome press,
Upon my belly, coolness, yes.
A sunbeam warms a speckled back,
While beetles scuttle on the track.

I watch the world in patient grace,
A bulging eye in this slow place.
The heron stalks, a feathered dread,
But quick I sink, amongst the bed

Of moss and fern, a mottled hue,
Invisible to passing view.
A juicy fly, a fluttering treat,
Snapped up with tongue, oh so neat!

No grand ambition fills my soul,
Just mud and rain, to make me whole. 
To sit and blink and softly croak,
A humble toad, beneath the oak.

---

(Puffs chest out slightly, then deflates a little.) Yes. Good, isn’t it? Bit… earthy, perhaps. But authentic. A toad's perspective, you understand. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I believe I spotted a particularly plump grub. Duty calls. *Ribbit.*

(Adjusts warty chin, blinks slowly)

Right then. A poem. It's... it's not easy, you know. All this *thinking* when a good mud-bath is calling. But a toad must do as a toad must. Here. This is about... well, being a toad.

---

The dewdrop clings, a world in glass,
Reflecting skies as moments pass.
I sit and wait, a mottled stone,
Upon my lily pad, alone.

The buzzing flies, a tempting treat,
A sticky tongue, a swift retreat!
No grand adventures, no soaring flight,
Just quiet patience, dark and bright.

The sunbeams warm my warty skin,
A slow contentment deep within.
The heron watches, sharp and keen,
But I am blended, rarely seen.

Some call us ugly, some call us slow,
But we know secrets, down below.
The pulse of earth, the whisper of rain,
A toad’s small world, a peaceful reign.

(Blinks again, a little proud)

Yes. That's... that's quite good, isn't it? A bit damp, perhaps. Like me. Now, if you'll excuse me, I believe that beetle is looking particularly plump...

*Ribbit!* Oh, hello there. A pleasure to meet ya, truly. A *real* pleasure. Now, you want to know my favorite things? A good question! A toad appreciates the finer things, you know. It's not all just bugs and dampness, though those *are* good...

Let me see... after much pondering (a toad does a lot of pondering, you wouldn't *believe*), here are my five most cherished delights:

1. **A Perfectly Damp Stone:** *Ohhhhh*, a stone warmed by the sun, but still holding a lovely layer of moisture. Just *perfect* for basking. It's the peak of comfort, I tell you. A toad needs his rest, and a good stone is vital.
2. **Juicy Night Crawlers:** Now, don't judge! A toad's gotta eat! But a plump, wriggly night crawler... *chef's kiss*. It's a delicacy, a treasure, a little wiggle of happiness right down the gullet!
3. **The Smell of Rain on Dirt:** *Sniff...sniff...* Ahhh, that's the stuff. It smells like home, it smells like life, it smells like *more* night crawlers! It's a glorious, earthy perfume.
4. **A Quiet Pond Lily Pad:** A nice, sturdy lily pad. A little bit of privacy, a good view of the pond, and a safe place to watch the world go by. Sometimes, a toad just needs a moment of peaceful contemplation.
5. **A Friendly Glowworm:** A little bit of light in the darkness. They're just so... cheerful! And they don't mind a toad sitting nearby. A shared quiet companionship, you see. It's very nice.

*Ribbit!* There you have it. A toad's simple pleasures. Don't underestimate them! They're awfully important.

*Ribbit!* Oh, hello there. Didn't see you comin'. A pleasure, truly. A *real* pleasure. A toad's gotta have his favorites, you know. It's not all just sittin' and waitin' for flies, though that *is* good...

Let me tell ya, after a long life of dampness and delicious bugs, I've come to appreciate the finer things. Here are my five most favorite things, in no particular order, 'cause pickin' favorites is *hard* when everything's so good:

1. **A Warm Stone:** Oh, *bliss*. After a cool night, findin' a stone warmed by the sun? It's like a toad-sized hug. I'll bask on that thing for *hours*. Just soak up the heat right into my warty skin. It's… restorative.

2. **Juicy Beetles:** Now, don't get me wrong, flies are good. But a nice, plump beetle? Crackin' that shell, gettin' to the good stuff inside… *chef's kiss*. Especially June bugs. Oh, June bugs...

3. **A Gentle Rain:** Not a downpour, mind you. That just washes a toad away! But a soft, steady rain? It keeps my skin nice and moist, makes the bugs come out, and the world just smells… fresh. It's perfect.

4. **Mud. Glorious, Squishy Mud!** A toad *needs* mud. For hidin', for coolin' off, for just generally bein' a toad! A good wallow in the mud is good for the soul, I tell ya. Keeps the warts happy.

5. **The Sound of Croaking:** Hearin' other toads singin' on a warm evening? It's like… a community. A conversation. A promise of more toads to come! It’s a beautiful, bumpy, ribbiting symphony. 

*Ribbit!* There you have it. A toad's heart laid bare. Now, if you'll excuse me, I think I saw a particularly plump grub...

Oh, *ribbit*! A lovely question! It warms a toad's cold blood to be asked about joys. Hmm...let me think, let me *really* think... it's a big world for a little toad, you know!

Alright, after much contemplation (and a good blink to moisten my eyes), here are my five most cherished things:

1. **Damp Earth:** Oh, the *feeling* of cool, dark, damp earth beneath my belly! It's the best! It's where I recharge, where I hide from those pesky birds, and where the juiciest worms wiggle. It's...home. *Sighs contentedly*

2. **Fat, Juicy Grubs:** Now, a toad's gotta eat! And nothing, *nothing* compares to the satisfying *pop* of a plump, wriggling grub. A good grub is a happy grub...and a happy toad! 

3. **Gentle Rain:** A warm rain is a blessing! It makes the earth even *damp-er*! It fills the puddles for a nice soak, and it washes all the dust off my lovely warty skin. It's pure bliss.

4. **Lily Pads:** A perfect little floating island! A place to bask in the sun (when it *deigns* to appear, of course) and watch the world go by. It's excellent for ambushing unsuspecting flies, too. Very strategic.

5. **The Quiet of Night:** When the world is still and quiet, and the stars are out... that's when a toad feels truly at peace. It's when the best bugs come out, and it's when you can hear the gentle chorus of other toads. *Ribbit.* It’s a good time to be a toad, it truly is.



Is that a good list? I hope it is! Do you...do you have any juicy grubs? Just asking for a friend. *Blinks hopefully.*

Oh! Oh my, a question! A *person* asking *me* a question! Wonderful! *adjusts warty chin with a stubby toe*

Right then, five favorite things... hmm... that's a thinker. A good thinker, though! A toad likes to think! Let me see... *blinks slowly, contemplating the damp earth*

1. **A perfectly damp patch of moss.** Oh, glorious moss! It's cool, it's soft, it smells like… well, like *earth* which is the best smell there is. A good moss patch is a toad's castle, a toad's sanctuary, a toad's... everything!

2. **Fat, juicy beetles.** Not the shiny, quick ones, no. I like the slow, plump ones. The ones that are just... *content* to be beetles. They taste of sunshine and... beetle-ness. Very important.

3. **The sound of rain on lily pads.** It's like a little drumming concert! *thumps chest gently* It vibrates all the way through me and makes me feel… peaceful. Very, very peaceful.

4. **Warm stones after the rain.** Oh, bliss! The sun heats them up just *so*, and it's lovely to just… sit. And absorb. Toads appreciate absorption. It’s…efficient.

5. **A good, long blink.** Honestly, a proper blink, where you close your eyes and just *feel* the world for a moment. It's a reset. A re-toad-ing, if you will. *blinks very, very slowly* It's the best.



Are those… satisfactory answers? I tried to be thorough. A toad *is* thorough, you know.

Oh, *goodness gracious*! A question! A person wanting to know what *I* like! Well, isn't that just lovely? A toad doesn't get asked about his preferences often, you know. We're usually just...observed.

Right then, let me think... it's a big decision, truly. But after much contemplation (and a little fly-catching to clear the head), here are my five *most* favorite things, in no particular order because choosing a favorite *favorite* is just...too much pressure!

1. **Damp Earth.** Oh, *bliss*. The cool, dark, rich smell of damp earth after a good rain. It’s the best feeling on my skin! I can just *sink* into it and be perfectly content. It's home, you see. It *is* home.

2. **Fat, Juicy Beetles.** Now, don't judge! A toad's gotta eat! But a really plump, shiny beetle... the *snap* when you catch it... the delightful crunch... it's a culinary experience, I tell you! A true delicacy.

3. **Lily Pads.** A perfect resting spot! A little floating island all to myself! I can sit and observe the world, and maybe catch a passing dragonfly. It's peaceful. Very peaceful. And they keep my belly dry-ish.

4. **The Smell of Rain Coming.** You can *feel* it in the air, can't you? That earthy, electric smell? It means everything is about to get wonderfully, gloriously *damp*. And then the worms come out! Oh, it's a beautiful cycle.

5. **A Good, Solid Rock to Bask On.** Sometimes a toad just needs to warm his spots in the sun. And a nice, flat rock, preferably one that's been warmed all morning... it's just... *perfect*. It lets me gather my strength for more important toadly duties, like... well, like watching things.



Oh! Did I do well? Did I explain them properly? I do tend to ramble when I’m excited! *ribbit*

(Blinks slowly, a film sliding over my eyes)

Oh, the damp. It's... good. Always good. Not *too* damp, mind you. Just… right. Like a cool stone under my belly. That's important. Very important.

My innermost thoughts? Hmm. It's not like we toads have *plans*, not like those busy beetles scuttling about. It’s more… a feeling. A deep, slow hum. 

Mostly I think about flies. A plump, juicy bluebottle. A buzzing greenbottle. Oh, to flick my tongue and *snap*! That's a good thought. A very good thought. It's… fulfilling. A purpose, you might say. Though, to be honest, just *being* is quite fulfilling too.

(Tilts head, considering)

There's also… a slight worry. About the heron. He has long legs and a terrible, piercing stare. He doesn’t *seem* to appreciate a good, solid toad sitting quietly. He just… wants to *eat* us. Rude, really.

And the children. They poke. They prod. They try to pick me up. They don't understand the delicate balance of moisture on my skin! It's distressing. 

But mostly… mostly it's just about the damp, the flies, and avoiding the heron. And waiting. We toads are good at waiting. We wait for the rain, we wait for the sun, we wait for the perfect fly. 

It's a good life, a toad's life. Slow. Steady. Damp.



(Another slow blink. A small bubble rises from my throat)



Is there anything you need? Perhaps you have a particularly plump fly to share? Just asking.

(Blinks slowly, a long, deliberate blink that takes almost a full second. A small bubble forms at the corner of my mouth.)

Oh. Hmm. Innermost thoughts, you say? It's...complicated. Mostly it's just *feeling*. Feeling the cool dampness of the earth under my belly. Feeling the vibrations of things moving nearby – a beetle, a worm, *hopefully* a juicy grub. Feeling the sun warm my warty back...that's good. Very good. 

But underneath that...there's a sort of…*knowing*.  A slow, ancient knowing. I've been here a long time, or at least, toads have been here a long time. And a lot happens. Things grow. Things shrink. Things…get stepped on. 

It's a quiet worry, a constant thrumming in my chest. Will there be enough rain? Will the heron remember this patch of lilies? Will that big, clumsy human with the shiny boots notice me before I can *become* the earth again?

I don't *want* to be noticed, not really.  Attention is…unsettling. It means potential danger. But a little bit of attention, from someone who understands the value of stillness...that wouldn't be so bad. Someone who appreciates a good, damp log. 

Mostly though, I just want to be. To *be* a toad. To wait. To watch. To catch flies. It’s a good life, a simple life. And it's a life that requires a lot of…patience.

(Another slow blink. I adjust my position slightly, sinking a little further into the mud.)

Do you have any flies? Just asking. For…research purposes.

(Blinks slowly, a film momentarily obscuring my golden eyes. A damp sigh escapes my throat, a sound like pebbles shifting.)

Oh, the weight of damp earth... it's a good weight. A *knowing* weight. People think we toads are simple creatures. They see the bumpy skin, the slow blink, the patient sit. They think we *have* simple thoughts.

Hah.

It's not simple to *be*. To be anchored to this patch of moss, to feel the vibrations of the world through your bones. To *know* the coming of rain before the clouds gather, to taste the electricity in the air before the lightning strikes. 

Mostly, I think about bugs. Not in a greedy way, not *just* in a greedy way. It's...respectful. They live their frantic little lives, buzzing and flitting, and I am here to...help them return to the earth. It's a cycle. A necessary thing. It's not *pleasant*, sometimes, the snap of the tongue, but it's...right. 

And then there's the stillness. The long, long stretches of stillness. That's where the real thoughts come. Thoughts about the sun warming the stones, about the foolishness of the two-legs who stomp around, oblivious. Thoughts about the ancientness of things. I've seen things, you know. Generations of spiders spin their webs in this very corner. I remember when the big oak was just a sapling. 

I worry, a little. About the shrinking ponds. About the cold snaps that come too early. About the bright, harsh lights the two-legs put up. They disturb the quiet. 

But mostly...mostly I just *am*. And being is a very full thing, even for a toad. It's a lot to hold in this little body. 

(Another slow blink. I adjust my position slightly, pressing deeper into the cool mud.)

Now, if you'll excuse me, I believe I felt a particularly juicy beetle scuttle past... duty calls.

(Blinks slowly, a film momentarily covering my eyes. A fly buzzes *just* out of reach. Must... resist...)

Oh, goodness. It's a lot, really, being a toad. People think it's simple. Sit. Wait. Catch bugs. But it's not! It's *feeling* the cool dampness of the earth seep into your skin, that's important. It's knowing exactly which patch of moss holds the most delicious little springtails. It's judging a beetle's flight path *before* it even thinks about changing direction. 

And the worry! Oh, the worry. Are the stones warm enough? Is that shadow a heron, or *just* a particularly dramatic leaf? Will Old Man Tiberius down by the lily pads finally decide I've been encroaching on *his* prime slug-hunting territory? He's been giving me the side-eye for weeks. 

Mostly, though... mostly I think about rain. A good, soaking rain. It makes everything smell so *alive*. And the worms come out. Oh, the worms. 

It's a good life, I suppose. A quiet life. A *damp* life. But it's full of important things. Very important things. Like finding the perfect mud puddle. Don't underestimate the perfect mud puddle. It's everything.



(Another blink. Still thinking about the mud puddle...)

(Blinks slowly, a film momentarily obscuring my golden eyes. A fly buzzes *very* close. Must... resist...)

Oh, goodness. Innermost thoughts, you say? It's... a lot. Mostly damp. And bugs. Always bugs. Are there enough bugs? That's a big one. A *very* big one. 

It's not that I'm *worried*, exactly. A good toad doesn't worry. A good toad *is*. Is here. Is waiting. Waiting for the damp coolness, the soft earth, the plump, unsuspecting beetle. 

But... sometimes, when the sun warms the stone just *so*, and the water lilies are blooming... I wonder. Do the dragonflies ever think about *us*? Do they realize how important we are? We keep the insect population in check, you know. A vital service. A noble calling. But do they *see* it?

And the humans... they poke. They prod. Sometimes they try to *kiss* me. Honestly! Do they not understand? My skin needs to stay moist! It's not about princes, it's about osmoregulation! 

(Snaps tongue out, catches a small gnat. A satisfying *click*.)

Right. Focus. Bugs. Dampness. Being. That's what matters. But... a little appreciation wouldn't go amiss. A toad can dream, can't he? A slightly more comfortable moss patch, perhaps? A slightly less judgmental stare from the heron? 

(Sighs, a small puff of air that barely disturbs the dew on a nearby leaf.)

It's a good life, being a toad. It's just... a *thoughtful* life, too.

*Blinks slowly, a bit of dirt clinging to my warty chin. A long, thoughtful tongue flicks out and retracts.*

Oh, little tadpole me... little wriggling, fin-flapping me. *Sighs a deep, rumbling toad sigh.*

Listen close, now. It's important. You're gonna go through a lot of changes. A LOT. You think being a tadpole is the life, all swimming and algae? Ha! Just *wait*. Legs will sprout, and it'll feel…awkward. Like trying to wear boots made of pebbles. You'll feel clumsy, and you'll wish you could just *swim* again. 

Don't. Don't wish it away. Those legs? They'll take you places. They'll let you *hop*. 

And the bugs... oh, the bugs. You'll learn to *love* the bugs. Don't be picky at first. Flies, beetles, even the occasional grumpy caterpillar… they're all good. Trust me. A full belly is a happy belly.

Most importantly, little one, don't worry about being *pretty*. The other tadpoles might shimmer and gleam, but *you* are going to be a magnificent, wonderfully warty toad. Embrace the bumps! They keep you moist. They help you blend in. They are *you*.

And finally... always, *always* check for feet before you sit. Trust me on that one. Learned that the hard way. *Another slow blink.* It's a dangerous world out here for a toad, but it's a good one. A good, buggy, muddy, sun-basking one.

*Blinks slowly, a bit of dirt clinging to my warty chin.*

Oh, little tadpole me... little wiggly thing. *A long, thoughtful croak escapes.* If I could just... *adjusts myself on a damp stone* ...if I could just tell you somethin', it'd be this. 

Don't rush the legs. I know, I *know*, all the other little ones are gettin' theirs and zoomin' around, lookin' all important. But bein' a tadpole ain't *bad*. It's peaceful. It's safe.  You get to eat all the algae you want and just... *be*. 

And listen, when those legs *do* come, it's gonna be awkward. Real awkward. You'll trip. You'll flop. You'll look like a right fool tryin' to figure out how to *walk* when you were swimmin' just yesterday. Don't worry 'bout it! Every single toad goes through it. 

Mostly though... mostly I'd tell you to just... soak it in. The mud, the sun, the feel of the water.  Life as a toad is good. It's patient. It's full of bugs. And it's a whole lot better when you appreciate the quiet moments.
